narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course gave me the opportunity to practice my writing skills. Prof G is very thorough in his line edits and provides helpful feedback. Most importantly, Prof G encourages different ways to view our history than those that we as students, I believe, often somewhat simplistically tend towards.
I learned about Yale and America obviously, but I learned a lot more about what it means to study history and how to do it well.
fun facts about yale (but in a more substantive way than that might sound)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Easily one of the best courses ive taken at yale, no improvements!
Prof Gitlin is the strength! No nicer or smarter human being walks this earth.

strengths: prof G is just so charming it's hard not to be engaged, strengths include course organization and emphasis on student presentations, prof G very willing to discuss things that aren't strictly academic (e.g. contemporary yale culture) that make for a much more fun class

weaknesses: too many readings to know which are very important. but honestly hardly any

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: student presentations good, amount of material sent out before class sometimes overwhelming

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: absolutely, especially if they want to end their Yale career on a high, nostalgic note
Yes! A delightful course with a delightful professor.
PLEASE take a class with Professor Gitlin before you graduate!!! Best professor Ive ever had the pleasure of meeting and being taught by!

YES! You've probably heard the hype surrounding Yale and America, and I was skeptical myself of whether it would live up to the expectations. It certainly did. Prof G is a gem-- there is no professor at Yale like him. All he really cares about is his students: that they're learning, that they're having fun. This was abundantly clear. He fought with the administration for months to allow an in-person class (the famous Grove St Cemetary tour), and it was successful. This is a great indicator of what Yale and America is like. Work-wise, it's fine... there is definitely a lot of reading, but you can skim it and be fine. Also, the readings are pretty interesting. There's a super short paper at the beginning of the class, and a long one at the end (15-20 pgs), and some other fun assignments sprinkled in (like writing and performing a song!). Prof G is a lenient grader as long as you are putting in the effort. Also, don't be scared by the number of people trying to take the course, we had 2 sections this year. One of those must-take classes at Yale!
u need to take this class simply to enjoy prof g's company, its more work than you might think - it's super fun but not a gut at all
